author: Ben Stinar
title: LeBron James' Official Injury Status For Lakers-Trail Blazers Game
text:
LeBron James' Official Injury Status For Lakers-Trail Blazers Game
LeBron James is on the injury report for Thursday's game.
On Thursday night, the Los Angeles Lakers will be in Oregon to play the Portland Trail Blazers.
For the game, they could be without one of their best players, as LeBron James is on the injury report.
James is averaging 24.3 points, 7.7 rebounds and 9.0 assists per contest while shooting 51.5% from the field and 39.4% from the three-point range in 49 games.
Via Underdog NBA: "LeBron James (injury management) questionable Thursday."
The Lakers are coming off a 100-97 loss (at home) to LaMelo Ball and the Charlotte Hornets.
James finished the loss with 26 points, seven rebounds, 11 assists, one steal and two blocks while shooting 10/22 from the field and 4/11 from the three-point range in 38 minutes of playing time.
Published |Modified

author: Guoke
title: 大力推进广西新能源产业技术创新
text:
江 魏
习近平总书记视察广西时所强调的“广西生态优势金不换”，为广西生态文明建设锚定了航向。在经济与生态协同发展的关键节点，推动新能源产业崛起成为必然战略抉择。能源安全牵系经济社会发展全局，培育清洁能源、推动绿色低碳转型是国际应对气候变化的共识。广西全力驱动新能源产业前行，而技术创新正是其高质量、可持续发展的核心引擎与绿色经济的根基。
聚智汇力，筑牢创新高地
新能源产业技术创新极具挑战，绝非单一主体能独自攻克。“智”是关键驱动力。汇聚多方智慧，协同合作，构建高效流动的良性系统，能激发创新活力。推动技术突破、产业升级，加速技术扩散，降低成本，提升效率，是新能源产业发展的必由之路。
在进一步全面深化改革大力发展新质生产力的背景下，政府要积极主动作为，牵头联合高校、科研机构和企业打造“新能源技术开源社区”，共享技术与设备，鼓励企业和个人开发者参与技术改进与创新，政府负责制定知识产权保护规则，并设立激励机制。同时，在新能源产业聚集区等建设“新能源技术中试加速器”，为中小企业和科研团队提供中试场地、设备和技术支持，帮助其将实验室成果快速转化为可市场化产品。
充分发挥广西区位优势，依托中国—东盟命运共同体建设和“一带一路”国际合作机制，借助区块链技术建立技术跨境合作平台。区块链的分布式账本、不可篡改及智能合约特性，能够有效解决跨境合作中的信任难题和知识产权保护问题，吸引东盟国家的科研机构和企业参与技术研发和项目合作，推动新能源技术的国际化。
此外，基于高度发展的数字技术，应充分利用云计算和虚拟现实技术构建虚拟实验室。在政府制定的共享实验室运营规则下，适当给予使用补贴，实现远程协同研发和实验模拟，对风电、光伏、储能等技术进行仿真测试和优化设计，打破地域限制，吸引全球顶尖人才参与研发，最大程度提升研发效率，降低研发成本。
高效协作，保障创新生态
新能源产业技术创新是一项系统性工程，要求政府各相关部门协同作战形成强大合力。
打破部门壁垒，构建创新性跨部门协调联动机制。打造一站式联合审批平台，运用数字化技术实现发改、科技、工信等多部门信息实时共享与同步审批，显著提高项目审批效率，减少企业在项目推进过程中的时间成本和精力损耗，加速新能源产业项目的落地实施。同时，建立政策协同矩阵，在政策制定初期，多部门可联合开展深入调研和研讨，使各部门政策围绕新能源产业创新目标协同发力，杜绝政策冲突与推诿现象，为新能源产业创新提供全方位的政策支持。
依据项目实时进度进行及时的保障与监督。建立动态调配机制，根据产业发展需求与项目实际进展情况，精准高效地调配资金，确保资金用在刀刃上，为重点项目和关键技术研发提供充足的资金保障。同时，健全动态监测体系，定期对技术创新项目进度、资金使用效益、人才培养成效等关键指标进行全面评估，依据评估结果及时优化调整支持策略，对于进展顺利的项目加大支持力度，对于遇到困难的项目及时调整资源分配或提供针对性的解决方案。
金融赋能，激活创新动能
推动金融机构与新能源企业加强合作沟通，发挥金融赋能作用，通过创新金融服务，精准对接供应链上中小企业融资需求，有效缓解其融资困境，提升资金流动性，进而增强整个供应链的韧性与竞争力。
针对当前新能源技术研发项目普遍面临的融资难、融资贵问题，传统的债券融资和股权融资方式难以满足其庞大的资金需求。为提高资产流动性和融资效率，可推出“新能源技术收益权证券化”产品，将新能源技术研发项目的未来收益进行打包，转化为可在金融市场交易的证券。同时，政府设立专项担保基金，降低投资者的风险敞口，增强市场信心，吸引更多社会资本参与新能源技术研发。
新能源产业供应链中的中小企业在技术创新和产品生产过程中，往往会面临资金压力，这在一定程度上制约了新能源技术的产业化和市场推广进程。可依托新能源产业链上的核心企业，搭建供应链金融服务平台。将产业链上的供应商、生产商、经销商等企业与金融机构紧密连接，通过提供应收账款质押融资、订单融资、仓单质押融资等金融服务，为中小企业提供有力的融资支持。
此外，可借鉴浙江、广东、重庆等地的经验，引入第三方评估机构对技术项目的收益潜力进行客观评估，有效避免因信息不对称导致的投资评估困难，确保项目顺利获得资金支持。
引育并举，厚植创新根基
人才引进与培育是筑牢创新根基的关键，根据“共生理论”与“知识溢出效应”，人才与产业各要素相互依存，应注重促进人才与产业协同进化；人才流动带来知识扩散，要坚持人才引进与培育双管齐下，推动创新。
在人才引进方面，构建“全球人才地图”与精准对接机制至关重要。详细标注新能源技术前沿地区与潜在人才分布，搭建线上线下融合平台，加强与国际科研机构、高校的合作，精准识别和吸引特定领域的顶尖人才。同时，秉持“异地孵化，本地转化”的思路，突破地域限制，在人才富集的城市设立人才飞地，为人才提供良好的科研场地与资源，待成果产出后输送至本地产业。
在人才培育方面，地方高校相关专业应根据新能源产业的实时发展动态更新教学内容，邀请新能源企业资深专家、工程师走进课堂，将行业最新技术与实践案例融入教学过程，启发学生对行业进行创新思考，提升研发动力与能力。建立新能源人才虚拟社区，整合高校、企业、科研机构资源，集聚产业技术人才群体，在社区交流、参与培训开展项目合作。
（作者单位：中共广西区委党校）
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->energy and resource
Economy, Business and Finance->business strategy and marketing

author: penta
title: How Radiant Heating and Cooling Systems Are Changing the HVAC Industry
text:
Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems have evolved significantly over the years, offering homeowners and businesses more energy-efficient and effective ways to regulate indoor temperatures. One of the most innovative advancements in HVAC technology is radiant heating and cooling, which provides an alternative to traditional forced-air systems. Unlike conventional HVAC methods that rely on circulating air, radiant systems use thermal radiation to directly heat or cool surfaces, creating a more natural and efficient climate control solution.
This article explores how radiant heating and cooling systems work, their benefits and drawbacks, and how they are reshaping the HVAC industry.
Understanding Radiant Heating and Cooling Systems Radiant HVAC systems operate by transferring heat through surfaces such as floors, walls, and ceilings rather than relying on ducted airflow. These systems leverage the principles of thermal radiation to achieve comfortable indoor temperatures with improved energy efficiency.
Types of Radiant Heating Systems Hydronic Radiant Heating: Utilizes a network of water-filled tubes installed beneath floors or behind walls to distribute heat. Commonly powered by boilers, solar thermal systems, or heat pumps. Offers superior energy efficiency compared to traditional forced-air heating. Electric Radiant Heating: Uses electric resistance cables or mats placed under floors to generate heat. More suitable for localized heating applications rather than whole-home systems. Ideal for retrofitting specific rooms, such as bathrooms and kitchens. Types of Radiant Cooling Systems Chilled Ceiling Panels: Cool water circulates through panels installed in ceilings, absorbing heat and lowering room temperatures. Works best in low-humidity environments to prevent condensation issues. Chilled Floor Systems: Similar to hydronic radiant heating, but instead of warming the floor, cool water reduces surface temperatures. Provides even cooling and eliminates drafts common in forced-air systems. Advantages of Radiant Heating and Cooling Radiant HVAC systems offer several advantages over traditional heating and cooling solutions, making them an attractive option for modern buildings.
1. Enhanced Comfort Unlike forced-air systems that create hot and cold spots, radiant heating and cooling provide consistent and even temperature distribution. Eliminates drafts and minimizes temperature fluctuations for improved comfort. 2. Energy Efficiency Radiant systems reduce energy consumption by eliminating duct losses, which can account for up to 30% of energy waste in conventional systems. Hydronic systems, in particular, operate at lower temperatures, making them compatible with renewable energy sources like solar and geothermal heating. 3. Improved Indoor Air Quality Since radiant systems do not rely on air circulation, they minimize the movement of dust, allergens, and pollutants, making them ideal for individuals with respiratory issues. 4. Silent Operation Traditional HVAC systems rely on fans and blowers that generate noise, whereas radiant systems operate silently, enhancing indoor tranquility. 5. Design Flexibility Radiant heating and cooling systems do not require ductwork, allowing for greater design freedom in architectural layouts. This feature is especially beneficial in homes with open floor plans and high ceilings. Challenges and Considerations of Radiant Systems Despite their benefits, radiant heating and cooling systems have some challenges that homeowners and building managers should consider.
1. Higher Upfront Costs Installing radiant systems can be more expensive than traditional HVAC due to the complexity of installation, particularly in existing structures. However, long-term energy savings often offset the initial investment. 2. Slow Temperature Response Time Unlike forced-air systems that quickly adjust temperatures, radiant systems take longer to heat or cool spaces. This limitation makes advanced thermostat programming essential for optimal efficiency. 3. Condensation Risks in Radiant Cooling In humid climates, radiant cooling systems may cause condensation, leading to potential moisture-related issues. Proper humidity control and ventilation strategies are necessary to prevent such problems. Integration with Modern HVAC Technologies The future of HVAC is increasingly focused on integrating radiant systems with other advanced climate control technologies to enhance efficiency and sustainability.
1. Smart Thermostats and Zoning Radiant systems paired with smart thermostats optimize energy use by regulating heating and cooling based on occupancy patterns. Zoning capabilities allow for personalized comfort in different areas of a home or building. 2. Hybrid HVAC Solutions Many modern buildings combine radiant heating with high-efficiency forced-air cooling or dehumidification systems to achieve optimal climate control year-round. This hybrid approach balances comfort, efficiency, and air quality. 3. Renewable Energy Integration Radiant systems are well-suited for renewable energy integration, such as solar thermal panels and geothermal heat pumps. This synergy reduces reliance on fossil fuels and lowers carbon footprints. Radiant Systems and the Future of HVAC As energy efficiency and sustainability become top priorities in the HVAC industry, radiant heating and cooling systems will play an increasingly important role. Innovations such as phase-change materials, AI-driven climate controls, and enhanced radiant panel technologies will further improve the viability of these systems.
Companies like Nardco Heating & Air Conditioning are at the forefront of integrating modern HVAC solutions, including radiant technology, to help homeowners and businesses achieve long-term energy savings and indoor comfort. With advancements in installation methods and system efficiencies, radiant HVAC solutions are set to become a mainstream option for climate control in the coming decades.
Conclusion Radiant heating and cooling systems represent a transformative shift in HVAC technology, offering superior comfort, energy efficiency, and indoor air quality improvements. While they come with higher upfront costs and specific installation requirements, their long-term benefits make them a worthwhile investment for many homeowners and businesses. As the HVAC industry continues to evolve, embracing radiant solutions will contribute to more sustainable, efficient, and comfortable living environments.
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->products and services

author: Tracy Ross
title: Teen Eldora ski patrollers rescue skier on Skywalker Couloir - The Colorado Sun
text: An Air National Guard Blackhawk helicopter hovers over a man who fell 2,000 feet down Skywalker Couloir in the Indian Peaks Wilderness, Sat. June 16 in Colorado. His rescue was initiated by Malachi Brooks, 17, and Bodhi Governson, 19, who began learning search-and-rescue skills on the junior ski patrol at Eldora resort when they were each 15. Governson is now a paid patroller while Brooks aims to become one this winter. The fallen skier survived. (Video courtesy of Rocky Mountain Rescue Group) Bodhi Governson and Malachi Brooks were just two ordinary guys, not yet 20, when they set out to ski Skywalker Couloir in the Indian Peaks Wilderness on June 16. By the end of the day, they’d be heroes for helping rescue a skier who fell at the top of a plunging descent and tomahawked more than 1,000 feet toward a rock outcropping. Skywalker is the main couloir on the south face of South Arapaho Peak. It’s described on 14ers.com as “very difficult” with three Star Wars-themed entrances into the 2,000-foot descent that starts at 13,200 feet and pitches to 55 degrees. Governson said the snow was slushy by the time he and Brooks dropped in. But they stopped at a 400-foot section in the middle of the couloir because the sun hadn’t hit it yet and it was still too icy to safely descend. Governson, from Longmont, is 19 and Brooks, from Boulder, is 17. Both have been skiing since they “were able to walk” and consider themselves “OK skiers.” Governson is a part-time paid patroller and Brooks is a volunteer patroller aiming to turn professional at Eldora ski area this winter. They both joined the junior ski patrol program at the Boulder County ski hill when they were 16 and 15, which Neil Sullivan, patrol director, said is a relatively difficult gig to get, with lots of kids applying. These guys are pretty special, though, Sullivan said. “Malachi is self-aware, a great skier and just absorbs things. He’s really present and like a sponge. Everything you say, you know it’s going in there and staying.” “Bodhi is calm but with a sense of eagerness,” Sullivan added. “He has confidence and humility. You look in his eyes and see this excitement. He’s looking forward to doing everything you’re telling him.” The Eldora junior patrol has 12 kids who start their training with Outdoor Emergency Class through the National Ski Patrol that lasts two nights a week from August to October. “Then they’re on the snow, around the professional patrol, learning what all the equipment is and the nature of the job,” Sullivan said. “They’re talked to and introduced to this whole thing the same way the pro patrol is.” They’re also exposed to all of the trauma pro patrol sees, which at Eldora, like most ski resorts , is significant. Though they can’t treat an injured skier until they’re 18, the young patrollers witness bones being splinted and skiers being loaded into sleds. They see head injuries, broken femurs and the occasional death. “They’re also there to assist, which could mean helping lift a backboard or loading a person into a sled,” Sullivan said. “They could be doing traffic control, or a couple of them might go out and close a run if that’s what we need. They provide a great workforce. And they’re given a lot of responsibility.” From first descent to first responder The many skills Governson and Brooks have been learning came into play during their first descent of Skywalker last weekend. While they were waiting for the sun to soften the narrow section of shaded snow they sat above so they could ski it, they witnessed a terrifying accident. A skier, identified only as a 47-year-old man, began his descent down the left side of the couloir. He lost control and began tumbling, making full body head-over-heels vertical rotations down the run. As they watched, Governson instinctively grabbed for his phone and dialed 911. Fortunately the call went through and a rescue was initiated. Brooks said his first thought was, “we need to figure out how to get down to him.” But he knew they couldn’t keep descending on skis because of the danger of slipping on the ice. “We needed to prioritize our safety to help him,” he said, repeating a key tenet in rescue training. So they carefully secured their skis to their backpacks, put on crampons, hiked to skiable snow and made turns for about 700 feet to the fallen skier. The rescuers won’t say what his injuries were because first responders are sworn to confidentiality by health privacy rules . That doesn’t surprise Sullivan, who says the teens are respectful and go by the book. “Their ability to recognize a situation and to listen and provide the care that’s necessary, both of them have developed so much of that,” he said. Emilie Jue, a technical field leader for Boulder-based Rocky Mountain Rescue Group, saw their training in action. She’s been with Rocky Mountain Rescue for seven years and has participated in 700 of the estimated 1,400 search and rescue missions the professional organization has performed, free of charge, during that period. She was the first person flown to the couloir via Medevac helicopter. Her day job is physicist. Jue arrived an hour and a half after Governson made his call. As the helicopter neared the accident, she spotted the guys, wearing bright red shirts. When the aircraft set her down, she saw they’d covered the patient in an orange emergency blanket. Her priority once she landed was to locate the patient, secure him and provide medical care, she said. “But when I was about 50 feet away, someone approached me and asked if I was ready for a medical report.” Both Governson and Brooks were wearing Eldora ski patrol T-shirts. She knows Eldora patrol responds to a high volume of accidents, so their association with the patrol “increased my confidence in what Bodhi and Malachi were saying,” she said. Governson gave her one of the most thorough medical reports she’s ever heard, and Brooks took impeccable notes. By the time she arrived, Governson had taken three sets of vitals and Brooks had documented them all. Once she learned Governson is an EMT, she told him, “‘There’s no reason I need to take over for you if you are willing to keep going.’ He said he was happy to, so I gave him a stethoscope. He was totally willing to keep on it as Malachi kept taking notes.” Based on the patient’s condition, location in the couloir and distance from a landing pad and the trailhead, Jue recommended an evacuation via a cable hoist beneath a helicopter. She asked the Rocky Mountain Rescue Team member running operations and the coordinator from the Emergency Services Unit of the Boulder County Sheriff to coordinate the resources. They tried to get a Black Hawk helicopter from Buckley Space Force Base but ended up using one from the High Altitude Air National Guard Aviation Training Site in Gypsum. Then the helicopter came, big, army green and menacing during combat. But out in the wilderness, headed for a skier who was merely chasing some fun and fell, it might as well have been a big, benevolent butterfly. This one carried two members of Vail Mountain Rescue Group who are also members of the Colorado Hoist Rescue Team . The team on scene, which had grown to seven, prepared the man to be hoisted on a cable into the Black Hawk’s belly. He was transported to the Nederland High School parking lot, where he was transferred to an ambulance and at around 4 p.m. taken to a hospital. Meanwhile, Jue and the other rescuers packed up and hiked out of the backcountry while the teens finished their epic ski descent and followed. The rescue had taken around five and a half hours, but Governson’s and Brooks’ day had been going for 10. They’d left their houses at 3:30 a.m. They’d climbed thousands of feet and skied thousands more. They’d broken out crampons and down climbed something sketchy. They’d kept it together every second of the rescue they launched while chasing their own high-risk, high-reward fun. Jue called what the teens did “very detailed, professional and well done.” She praised them for “witnessing something extremely hard and staying calm.” “They went into ski patrol mode instead of saying, ‘Oh [bleep] what do we do?’” she added. And she said the man who could have fallen to his death in Skywalker is doing better and has been discharged from the hospital. “Without any doubt, he is lucky that Bodhi and Malachi were in the couloir.” Type of Story: News Based on facts, either observed and verified directly by the reporter, or reported and verified from knowledgeable sources.

organizations.name: colorado sun an air national guard blackhawk
